div.head: To my Worthy and much Respected Friend, Mr. Thomas Hammon, of Grayes Inne Esquire.
div.p: IF the noble Scholler Nichod. Friseelimus, thought that his labour in Transferring six of Aristophanes his Comedies, out of the Originall Greeke into the Roman tongue, was worthy to be dedicated to six seueral, the most eminent Princes of his time, for Learning and Iudgement: Thinke it then no disparagment to you, to vndertake as well the Patronage, perusall of this Poem: Which as it exceedes the strict limits of the ancient Comedy (then in vse) informe, so it transcends them many degrees; both in the fulnesse of the Sceane, and grauity of the Subiect.

The History whereon it is grounded, hauing beene the selected Argument of many exquisite Poets: For what Pen of note, in one page or other
hath not remembred Troy, and bewayl'd the sacke, and subuersion of so illustrious a Citty▪ Which, although it were scituate in Asia, yet out of her ashes hath risen, two the rarest Phoenixes in Europe, namely London and Rome. Sir my acquaintance with your worth, and knowledge of your iudgement, were the chiefe motiues, inducing me to select you before many others: accept it, I intreate you, as fauourably as hee exposeth it willingly, who as he hath antecedently long, so futurely euer,

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: COurteous Reader: The Gold, Siluer, and Brasse Ages hauing beene many yeares since in the Presse, continuing the History from Iupiters Birth (the sonne of Saturne) to the Death of Hercules. This Iron Age (neuer till now Published,) beginneth where the other left, holding on, a plaine and direct course, from the second Rape of Hellen: (For she was in her minority rauished by Theseus the Friend of Hercules) not onely to the vtter ruine, and deuastation of Troy; but it, with the second Part, stretcheth to the Deathes of Hellen, and all those Kings of Greece, who were the vndertakers of that Ten yeares Bloody and fatall Seige. I presume the reading there of shall not prooue distastfull vnto any: First in regard of the Antiquity and Noblenesse of the History: Next because it includeth the most things of especiall remarke, which haue beene ingeniously Commented, and labouriously Recorded, by the Muses Darlings, the Poets: And Times learned Remembrancers; the Histriographers▪

Lastly, I desire thee to take notice, that these were the Playes often (and not with the least applause,) Publickely Acted by two Companies, vppon one Stage at once, and haue at sundry times thronged three seuerall Theaters, with numerous and mighty Auditories, if the grace they had then in the Actings, take not away the expected luster, hoped for in the Reading, I shall then hold thee well pleased, and therein, my selfe fully satisfied; Euer remaining thine as studious

div.stage: Enter King Priamus, Queene Hecuba, Hector, Troilus, Aeneas, Deiphobus, &c.

sp.speaker: Priamus.
sp.l: PRinces and Sonnes of Priam, to this end
Wee cal'd you to this solemne Parleance.
There's a deuining spirit prompts mee still,
That if we new begin Hostility,
The Grecians may be forc't to make repayre
Of our twice ruin'd walls, and of the rape
Done to our sister faire Hesione.
Aeneas. I am my princely Soueraigne of your minde,
And can by grounded arguments approoue
Your power and potency: what they twice demolish't,
Is now with strength and beauty rear'd againe.
Your Kingdome growne more populous and rich,
The youth of Troy irregular and vntam'd,
Couetous of warre and martiall exercise.
From you and siluer tressed Hecuba
Fifty faire sonnes are lineally deriu'd,
All Asiaes Kings are in your loue and league,
Their royalties as of your Empire held.
Hector and Hectors brothers are of power
To fetch your sister from the heart of Greece,
Where she remaines imbrac't by Telamon.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Aeneas, your aduise assents with vs.
How stand our sonnes vnto these wars inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: In mine opinion we haue no iust cause
To rayse new tumults, that may liue in peace:
Warre is a fury quickly coniured vp,
But not so soone appeased.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What iuster cause
When the whole world takes note to our disgrace,
Of this our Troy, twice rac't by Hercules.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And faire Hesione rapt hence to Greece,
Where she still liues coopt vp in Salamine.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troy, was twice rac't, and Troy deseru'd that wracke,
The valiant (halfe Diuine bred) Hercules,
Redeem'd this Towne from blacke mortality,
And my bright Aunt from death, when he surcharg'd
The virgin fedde, Sea-monster with his club.
For my owne Grand-sire great Laomedon,
Denied the Heroe, both the meede propos'd,
And most (ingratefull) shut him from the Gates:
Troy therefore drew iust ruine on it selfe:
Tis true, our Aunt was borne away to Greece,
Who with more iustice might transport her hence,
Then he whose prise she was? bold Telamon
For ventring first vpon the wals of Troy,
Alcides gaue her to the Salmine Duke.
Detayning her? whom keepes he but his owne?
Were she my prisoner I should do the like.
By Ioue she's worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then of force,
Shee must be worth the fetching.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Fetch her that list: my reuerent King and father,
If you pursue this expedition,
By the vntaunted honor of these armes
that liue imblazon'd on my burnish't shield,
It is without good cause, and I deuine
Of all your flourishing line, by which the Gods
haue rectified your fame aboue all Kings,
Not one shal liue to meate your Sepulchre,
Or trace your funerall Heralds to the Tombes
Of your great Ancestours: oh for your honour
Take not vp vniust Armes.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Prince Hectors words
Will draw on him the imputation
Of feare and cowardesie.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Fie brother Hector,
If our Aunts rape, and Troyes destruction̄
Bee not reueng'd, their seuerall blemishes
The aged hand of Time can neuer wipe
From our succession.
'Twill be registred
That all King Priams sonnes saue one were willing
And forward to reuenge them on the Greekes,
Onely that Hector durst not.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Ha, durst not didst thou say? effeminate boy,
Go get you to your Sheepe-hooke and your Scrip,
Thou look'st not like a Souldier, there's no fire
Within thine eyes, nor quills vpon thy chinne,
Tell me I dare not? go, rise, get you gone:
Th'art fitter for young Oenons company
Then for a bench of souldiers: here comes one,
Antenor is returned.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Welcome Antenor, what's the newes from Greece?

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: Newes of dishonour to the name of Priam,
Your Hignesse Sister faire Hesione:
Esteem'd there as a strumpet, and no Queene;
(After complaint) when I propos'd your Maiesty
would fetch her thence perforce, had you but seene
With what disdainefull pride, and bitter taunts
They tost my threats: 'twould haue inflam'd your spleene
With more then common rage, neuer was Princesse
So basely vs'd: neuer Embassadour
With such dishonour sent from Princes Court,
As was then from that of Telamons,
Of Agamemnons and the Spartan Kings.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: I shall not dye in peace, if these disgraces
Liue vnreueng'd.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: By Ioue wee'le fetch her thence,
Or make all populous Greece a Wildernesse,
Paris a hand, wee are friends, now Greece shall finde
And thou shalt know what mighty Hector dares.
When all th'vnited Kings in Armes shall rue
This base dishonour done to Priams blood.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Heare Gracious sir, my dreame in Ida Mount,
Beneath the shadow of a Cedar sleeping.
Celestiall Iuno, Venus, and the Goddesse
Borne from the braine of mighty Iupiter.
These three present me with a golden Ball,
On which was writ, Detur pulcherrimae,
Giue't to the fairest: Iuno proffers wealth,
Scepters and Crownes: saith, she will make me rich.
Next steps forth Pallas with a golden Booke,
Saith, reach it me, I'le teach the Litterature,
Knowledge and Arts, make thee of all most wise.
Next smiling Venus came, with such a looke
Able to rauish mankinde: thus bespake mee,
Make that Ball mine? the fairest Queene that breathes,
I'le in requitall, cast into thine armes.
How can I stand against her golden smiles,
When beautie promist beauty? shee preuayl'd:
To her I gaue the prise, with which shee mounted
Like to a Starre from earth shott vp to Heauen.
Now if in Greece (as some report) be Ladies
Peerelesse for beauty, wherefore might not Paris
By Venus ayde sayle hence to Grecia,
And quit the rape of faire Hesione,
By stealing thence the Queene most beautifull,
That feedes vpon the honey of that ayre?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: That amorous Goddesse borne vpon the waues
Assist thee in thy voyage, we will rigge
A royall fleete to waft thee into Greece.
Aeneas with our sonne Deiphobus,
And other Lords shall beare thee company.
What thinke our sonnes Hector and Troylus
Of Paris expedition?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: As an attempt the Heauens haue cause to prosper.
Go brother Paris, if thou bring'st a Queene,
Hector will be her Champion; then let's see
What Greeke dare fetch her hence.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Straight giue order
To haue his Fleet made ready.

div.stage: Enter Cassandra with her haire about her eares.

sp.speaker: Cassan.
sp.l: Stay Priam, Paris cease, stay Troian Peeres
To plot your vniuersall ouerthrow.
What hath poore Troy deseru'd, that you should kindle
flames to destroy it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What intends Cassandra?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: To quench bright burning Troy, to secure thee,
To saue old Priam and his fifty sonnes.
(The royal'st issue, that e're King I enioy'de)
To keepe the reuerent haires of Hecuba,
From being torne off by her owne sad hands.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Cassandra's madde.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: You are mad, all Troy is madde.
And railes before it's ruine.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What would my sister?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Stay this bold youth my brother, who by water
Would sayle to bring fire which shall burne all Troy.
Stay him, oh stay him, ere these golden roofes
Melt o're our heads before these glorious Turrets
Bee burnt to ashes. Ere cleare streames Simois
Runne with bloud royall, and Scamander Plaine,
In which Troy stands bee made a Sepulchre
To bury Troy, and Troians.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Away with her, some false deuining spirit
Enuying the honour we shall gaine from Greece,
Would trouble our designements.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Royall sir,
Cassandra is a Vestall Prophetesse,
And consecrate to Pallas; oft inspir'd,
Then lend her gracious audience.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: So let our Aunt
Bee still a slaue in Greece, and wee your sonnes
Bee held as cowards.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Let Antenors wrongs
Bee basely swallowed, and the name of Troy
Be held a word of scorne.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Then let Troy burne,
Let the Greekes clap their hands, and warme themselues
At this bright Bone-fire: dream'd not Hecuba
The night before this fatall Youth was borne,
That shee brought forth a fire-brand?

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: 'Tis most true.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: And when King Priam to the Preist reueal'd
This ominous dreame, hee with the Gods consulted,
And from the Oracle did this returne,
That the Childe borne should stately Illion burne.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And well the Prophet guest, for my desire
To visit Greece, burnes with a quenchlesse fire:
Not from this flaming brand shall I be free,
Till I haue left rich Troy, and Sparta see.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Yet Hecuba, ere thou thy Priam loose,
And Priam ere thou loose thy Hecuba,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Away with her.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Why speakes not in this case Andromache?
Thou shalt loose a Hector, who's yet thine.
Why good Aeneas dost thou speech forbeare?
Thou hop'st in time another Troy to reare,
When this is sackt, and therefore thou standst mute,
All strooke with silence; none assist my suite.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Force her away and lay her fast in hold.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Then Troy, no Troy, but ashes; and a place
Where once a Citty stood: poore Priam, thou
That shalt leaue fatherlesse fifty faire sonnes,
And this thy fruitfull Queene, a desolate widdow;
And Ilium now no Pallace for a King,
But a confused heape of twice burnt bricke.
They that thy beauty wondred, shall admire
To see thy Towers defac'd with Greekish fire.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou art no Sibill, but from fury speak'st,
Not inspiration we reguard thee not.
Come valiant sonnes, wee'le first prepare our ships,
And with a royall Fleete well rigg'd to sea
Seeke iust reuenge for faire Hesione.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, manet Paris, to him Oenon who in his going out Plucks her backe.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Know you not mee?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: View mee well.
And what I am, my lookes and teares will teach thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oenon? what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: To see Ida bare
Of her tall Cedars, to see shipwrights square
The trunks of new feld Pines: Asking the cause,
So many Hatchets, Hammers, Plowes and Sawes
Were thither brought: They gan mee thus to greete,
With these tall Cedars we must build a fleete
For Paris; who in that must sayle to Greece,
To fetch a new wife thence.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And my faire Oenon,
Know that they told truth, for 'tis decreed
Euen by the Gods behest, that I should speed
Vpon this new aduenture: The Gods all,
That made mee iudge to giue the golden Ball.
Harke, harke, the Saylers cry aboard, aboard;
The Winde blowes faire, fare-well.

sp.speaker: Oenon.
sp.l: Heare me one word.
By our first loue, by all our amorous kisses,
Courtings, imbraces, and ten thousand blesses
I coniure thee, that thou in Troy may'st stay.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: They cry aboard, and Paris must away.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: What need'st thou plowe the seas to seeke a wife▪
Hauing one here, to hazard thy sweete life,
Seeking a Strumpet through warres fierce alarmes,
And haue so kind a wife lodg'd in thine armes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sweete Oenon, stay me not, vnclaspe thine hold.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Not for Troyes crowne or all the Sun-gods Gold▪
Canst thou? oh canst thou thy sweete life indanger,
And leaue thine owne wife to seeke out a stranger?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I can, farewell.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Oh yet a little stay.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Let go thine hold, or I shall force my way.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Oh do but looke on me, yet once againe.
Though now a Prince, thou wast an humble swaine,
And then I was thine Oenon. (Oh sad fate)
I craue thy loue, I couet not thy state;
Still I am Oenon: still thou Paris are
The selfe-same man, but not the selfe-same heart:

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Vntie, or I shall breake thy charming band,
Neptune assist my course: thou Ioue my hand.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Most cruell, most vnkind, hadst thou thus said
The night before thou hadst my Maiden-head,
I had beene free to chuse, and thou to wiue;
Not widdowed now, my husband still aliue.

div.stage: Enter King Menelaus, King Diomed, Thersites, a Lord Embassadour with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: King Diomed, Sparta is proud to see you,
Your comming at this time's more seasonable,
In that wee haue imployment for your wisedome
And royall valour.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: The Christian Scepter now in contrauersie
(As this Embassadour hath late inform'd)
Despising that vsurping hand, which long
Hath against Law and Iustice swayd and borne it,
Offers it selfe to your protection.
Is it not so my Lord?

sp.speaker: Embassa.
sp.l: You truely vnderstand our Embasie.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Menelaus!

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What saith Thersites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: That Heauen hath many Starres in't, but no eyes,
And cannot see desert. The Goddesse Fortune
Is head-winkt, why else should she proffer thee
Another Crowne that hath one: (Grand Sir Ioue)
What a huge heape of businesse shalt thou haue,
Hauing another Kingdome? being in Creete,
Sparta will go to wracke, being in Sparta,
Creete will to ruine: To haue more then these
Such a bright Lasse as Hellen: Hellen? oh!
'Must haue an eye to her too, fie, fie, fie,
Poore man how thou'lt bee pusl'd!

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Why thinkes Thersites my bright Hellens beauty
Is not with her faire vertues equaliz'd?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Yes, I thinke so, and Hellen is an asse,
But thou beleeu'st so too.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Thersites is a rayler.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: No, I disclaim't, I am a Counsellor.
I haue knowne a fellow matcht to a faire wife,
That hath had ne're a Kingdome: thou hast two
To looke to, (scarce a house) thou many Pallaces,
Hee scarce a Page, and thou a thousand seruants:
Yet hee hauing no more, yet had too much
To looke to one faire wife.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Were not the King
Well grounded in the vertues of his Queene,
Thy words Thersites might set odds betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: My Hellen? therein am I happiest.
Know Diomed, her beauty I preferre
Before the Crownes of Sparta, and of Creete.
Musicke! I know my Lady then is comming,
To giue kind welcome to King Diomed,
Strowe in her way sweete powders, burne Perfume,
And where my Hellen treads no feete presume.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: 'Twere better strowe horne-shauings.

div.stage: Enter Hellen with waiting Gentlewomen and Seruants.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: 'Tis told ys this Embassadour doth stay
To take my husband, my deare Lord away.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: True Hellen, 'tis a Kingdome calls me hence.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: A Kingdome! hath your Hellen such small grace,
That you preferre a Kingdome 'fore her face?
You value me too cheape, and doe not know
The worth and value of the face you owe.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I had rather haue a good Calues face.

sp.speaker: Hese.
sp.l: Theseus, that in my non-age did assaile mee,
And being too young for pastime, thence did haile me:
Hee, to haue had the least part of your blisse
Oft proffered mee a Kingdome for a kisse.
You surfeit in your pleasures, swimme in sport,
But sir, from henceforth I shall keepe you short.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Faire Queene, 'tis honour calls him hence away,

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What's that to Hellen, if shee'le haue him stay?
Say I should weepe at parting, (which I feare)
Some for ten Kingdomes would not haue a teare
Fall from his Hellens eye, but hee's vnkind,
And cares not though I weepe my bright eyes blind.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Great King, we haue discouer'd from the shoare
A gallant Fleete of ships, that with full sayle
Make towards the Port.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What number?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Some two and twenty Sayle.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Discouer them more amply, and make good the Hauen against them, till we know th'intent of their arriue.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: My Royall Lord I shall.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Embassadour this busines once blowne o're,
You shall receiue your answer instantly.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: You shall not goe and leaue your Hellen here,
Can I a Kingdome gouerne in your absence,
And guide so rude a people as yours is?
How shall I doe my Lord, when you are gone,
So many bleake cold nights to lye alone?
Y'haue vs'd mee so to fellowship in bed,
That should I leaue it, I should soone be dead:
Troth I shall neuer indure it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My sweete Hellen,
Was neuer King blest with so chaste a wife.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The newes? whence is their Fleete?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: From Troy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The Generall?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Priams sonne.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Their expedition?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: To seeke aduentures and strange Lands abroad,
And though now weather-beat, yet brauer men,
More rich in Iewells, costlier araide,
Or better featur'd ne're eye beheld,
Especially the Prince their Generall,
Paris of Troy one of King Priams sonnes.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Brauer then these our Lacedemons are?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Madam, by much.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: How is the Prince of Troy
To Menelaus mighty Spartans King?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Prince Menelaus is my Soueraigne Madam,
But might I freely speake without offence,
(Excepting Menelaus) neuer breath'd
A brauer Gallant then the Troian Prince.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What Intertainment shall wee giue these strangers?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What? but the choyce that Lacedemon yeelds,
If they come braue, our brauery let vs show,
That what our Sparta yeelds, their Troy may know:
Let them not say they found vs poore and bare.
Or that our Grecian Ladies are lesse faire
Then theirs: giue them occasion to relate
At their returne, how wee exceede their stare.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Hellen hath well aduis'd, and for the best
Her counsell with our honour doth agree,
All Spartaes pompe is for the Troians free.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Oh had I known their Landing one day sooner,
That Hellen might haue trim'd vp her attire
Against this meeting, then my radiant beauty
I doubt not, might in Troy be tearm'd as faire,
As through all Greece I am reputed rare.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter Paris, Aeneas, Deiphobus, Antenor, Menelaus and Diomed embrace Paris and the rest: Paris turnes from them and kisseth Hellen, all way shee with her hand puts him backe.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: 'Tis not the Spartan fashion thus to greet
Vpon the lips, when royall strangers meete.
I know not what your Asian Court-ship is.
Oh Ioue, how sweetely doth this Troian kisse?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Beare with a stranger Lady, though vnknowne;
That's practis'd in no fashion saue his owne.
Hee that his fault confesseth ne're offends,
Nor can hee iniure, that no wrong intends,

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: To kisse mee! why before so many eyes
The King could do no more: would fortune bring
This stranger there where I haue met the King,

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Patience, sweet Hellen, Troians welcome all,
You shall receiue the princeliest entertaine
Sparta can yeeld you, but some late affaires
About the Cretan scepter calls vs hence,
That businesse once determin'd wee are yours,
In the meane time faire Hellen bee't your charge
To make their welcome in my absence large.

div.stage: They all goe off with a flourish, onely Paris and Hellen keepe the Stage.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh Ioue my dreame! sweete Venus ayde my prayer,
And keepe thy word: behold a face more faire
Then thou thy selfe canst shewe, this is the same
Thou promist me in Ida, this I claime.
Giue me this face faire Venus, and that's all
I'le aske in guerdon of the golden Ball.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Of what rare mettall is this Troian made?
That one poore kisse hath power so to perswade,
Here at my lips the sweetnesse did beginne,
And since hath past through all my powers within:
Oh kisse mee if thou lou'st me once againe,
I feele the first kisse thrill through euery veine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Queene I must speake with you,

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Must?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hellen, I,
I haue but two wayes to take, to speake, or dye:
Grant my tongue pardon then, or turne your head
And say you will not, and so strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Liue and say on, but if your words offend,
If my tongue can destroy, you're neare your end.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh Ioue, that I had now an Angels voyce
As you an Angels shape haue, that my words
Might sound as spheare-like musicke in your eare.
That Ioue himselfe whom I must call to witnesse,
Would now stand forth in person to approoue
What I now speake, Hellen, Hellen I loue.
Chide mee, I care not; tell, your husband, doe,
Fearelesse of death, behold, I boldly woe.
For let mee liue, bright Hellen to inioy,
Or let mee neuer backe resayle to Troy:
For you I came, your fame hath hither driuen mee,
Whom golden Venus hath by promise giuen mee.
I lou'd you ere I saw you by your fame,
Report of your rare beauty to Troy came.
But more then bruite can tell, or fame emblazon
Are these diuine perfections that I gaze on.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Insolent stranger, is my Name so light
Abroad in Troy, that thou at the first sight
Shouldst hope to strum pet vs? thinks Priams sonne,
The Spartan Queene can be so easily wonne?
Because once Theseus rauisht vs from hence,
And did to vs a kind of violence:
Followes it therefore wee are of such price,
That stolne hence once, we should be rauish't twice?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That Theseus stole you hence (by Heauen) I praise him,
And for that act I to the skies will raise him.
That hee return'd you backe by Ioue I wonder,
Had I beene Theseus, hee that should asunder
Haue parted vs, and snatcht you from my bed:
First from my should shoulders haue tane this head.
Oh that you were the prize of some great strife,
And hee that winnes might claime you as his wife,
Your selfe should finde, and all the world should see
Hellen, a prise alone ordain'd for mee.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am not angry; who can angry be
With him that loues her? they that Paris see,
And heares the wonders and rare deedes you boast,
And warlike spoyles in which you glory most:
By which you haue attaind 'mongst souldiers grace,
None can beleeue you that beholds your face.
They that this louely Troian see, will say;
Hee was not made for warre, but amorous plays

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Loue amorous Paris then.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My fame to endanger?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I can be secret Lady.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: And a stranger?
Say I should grant thee loue, as thou shouldst clime
My long wisht bed; if at th'appointed time
The Winde should alter, and blow faire for Troy,
Thou must breake off in midd'st of all thy Ioy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Not for great Spartaes Crowne, or Asiaes Treasure,
(That exceedes Spartaes) would I loose such pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: would it were come to that.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Your Husband Menelaus hither bring,
Compare our shapes, our youth and euery thing,
I make you Iudgesse, wrong me if you can:
You needes must say I am the properer man.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I must confesse that too.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then loue mee Lady.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Had you then sett sayle,
When my virginity, and bed to enioy
A thousand gallant princely Suiters came?
Had I beheld thee first, I here proclaime,
Your feature should haue borne mee from the rest.
You come too late, and couet goods possest.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I came from Hellen, Hellens loue I craue,
Hellen I loue, and Hellen I must haue:
Or in this Prouince where I vent my mones,
I'le begge a Tombe for my exiled bones.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter. Menelaus, Diomed, Thersites with Spartan Lords: Aeneas, Deiphobus, Antenor, &c.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Now Prince of Troy, our businesse being o're
This day in Lacedemon, you shall feast
Paris, wee are proud of such a Princely guest.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Thus euery man is borne to his owne Fate.
Now it raines Hornes, let each man shield his Pate.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: This royalty extended to the welcome
Of Priams sonne, is more then Asiaes King
Would yeeld vnto the greatest Prince of Greece.
What is this Paris whom you honour so?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why askes my Queene?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: May not this proud, this beauty vanting Troian,
In a smooth browe hide blacke and rugged Treason?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Hee such an one? rather a giddy braine,
A formall traueller. King Diomed
Your censure of this Troian?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: A Capring, Carpet Knight, a Cushion Lord,
One that hath stald his Courtly trickes at home,
And now got leaue to publish them abroad
Did to a stranger Prince, it could not though
Leauen my zeale o you: speake the fayrest Queene
That euer spake, this night shall we agree
To consecrate to pleasure and delights:
Your husband left me charge I should inioy
All that the Court can yeeld: if all? then you
I would not for the world, but you should doe
All that the King your Lord commands you too:
Your King and husband, you sinne doubly still
When you assent not to obay his will:
Speake beauteous Queene. No? then it may be
Shee meanes by silence to accord with me:
I'le trye that presently, lend me your hand
Tis this I want, and by the Kings command
You are to let me haue it: more then this,
I want your lips to helpe me make a kisse.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh Heauen!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh loue, a ioy aboue all measure,
To touch these lips is more then heauenly pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Beshrew your amorous rhetorick that did proue
My husbands will commanded me to loue,
For but for that iniunction, Paris know
I would not yeeld such fauours to bestow
On any stranger, but since he commands,
You may take more then eyther lips or hands.
Do I not blush sweete stranger? if I breake
The Lawes of modesty, thinke that I speake,
But with my husbands tongue, for I say still
I would not yeeld, but to obey his will.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This night then without all suspition,
The rauishing pleasures of your royall bed
You may affoord to Paris: bitter Thersites,
King Diomed, and your seruants may suppose
By my late counterfeite distemperature
I ayme at no such happinesse, alas
I am a puny Courtier, a weake braine,
A braine-sicke young man; but Deuinest Hellen,
When we get safe to Troy.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: To Troy?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes Queene, by all the gods it is decreed,
That I should beare you thither; Priam knowes it,
And therefore purposely did rigge this Fleete,
To waft me hether; He and Hecuba,
My nine and forty brothers, Princes all
Of Ladies and bright Virgins infinite,
Will meete vs in the roade of Tenedos▪
Then be resolu'd for I will cast a plot
To beare you safe from hence!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: This Troyan Prince
Will's more then any Prince of Greece dares pleade,
And yet I haue no power to say him nay:
Well Paris I beshrew you with my heart,
That euer you came to Sparta (by my ioy
Queene Hellen lyes, and longs to be at Troy:)
Yet vse me as you please, you know you haue
My dearest loue, and therefore cannot craue
What Ile deny; but if reproach and shame
Pursue vs, on you Paris light the blame:
Ile wash my hands of all, nor will I yeeld
But by compulsion to your least demaund:
Yet if in lieu of my Kings intertaine,
You bid me to a feast aboord your ship,
And when you haue me there, vnknowne to me
Hoyse sayle, weigh Anchor, and beare out to Sea:
I cannot helpe it, tis not in my power
To let fal sayles, or striue with stretching oares
To row me backe againe: this you may do,
But sooth friend Paris He not yeeld thereto.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You shalbe then compell'd, on me let all
The danger waiting on this practise fall.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Castor and Pollux your two princely brothers
Are newly Landed, and to morrow next
Purpose for Lacedemon.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: On their approach
He lay my plot to escape away with Paris.
I haue it: you sir for some speciall reason
There comming keepe conceal'd, but when to morrow
You shal perceiue me neere the water port,
Euen when thou seest me ready to take Barge.
You apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Gracious Queene I do.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Take that farwel: now my fayre princely guest
All that belongs to you's to inuite Queene Hellen
Aboord your ship to morrow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Spartaes mirrour,
Will you vouchsafe to a poore wandring Prince
So much of grace, will your high maiesty
Daigne the acceptance of an homely banquet
Aboord his weather beaten Barke?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: No Friend,
The King my husband is from Sparta gone,
And I, til his returne, must needes keepe home:
Vrge me not I intreate, it is in vaine
Get me aboord, Ile nere turne backe againe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nor shall you Lady, Sparta nor all Greece
Shal fetch you thence, but Troy shal stand as high
On tearmes with Greece, as Greece hath stood with Troy.

sp.speaker: Spa. L.
sp.p: This is the Water-port, the Queenes royal guest, hath bound me to attendance, till the Prince and shee bee ready to take Water: Methinkes in this there should bee some tricke or other, she was once stolne away by Theseus, and this a gallant smooth fac'd Prince. The Kings from home, the Queenes but a Woman, the Troians ships new trim'd, the wind stands fayre, and the Saylors all ready aboord, sweetemeates and wine, good words and opportunity, and indeede not what? If both parties bee pleasde, but pleasde or not the musicke giues warning, are they not now vpon their entrance.

div.stage: Enter in state Paris, Hellen, Diomed, Thersites, Aeneas, Antenor, Deiphebus, &c. with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Health to your Maiesties, your Princely brothers
Castor and Pollux, being within two Leagues
Of this great Citty, come to visite you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My brothers stolne vpon vs vnawares.
Let me intreate thee royall Diomed,
And you Thersites, do me so much grace,
As giue them friendly meeting.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Queene we shall.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Our intertainment shall be giuen aboord,
Where I presume, they shall be welcome guests
To princely Paris.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: As to your selfe, faire Queene,

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Set forwards then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: We'le hoyse vp sayle, neere to returne againe.

div.stage: Exeunt the Troians with a great shout.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Our brother Menelaus gone for Creete?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Our loue to see him, makes vs loose much time:
Yet all our labour is not vainly spent,
Since we shall see our sister.

div.stage: Enter the Spartan Lord in hast.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.p: Princes, the Kings betray'd, all Greece dishonoured, the Queene borne hence, the Troians haue weigh'd anchor, and with a prosperous gale they beare from hence:
sp.l: Shouting and hurling vp their caps for ioy,
They crye farwel to Greece, amayne for Troy.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: The Queene borne hence, with that smooth traytor Paris.
See princes with what pride they haue aduanc'd
The Armes of Tray vpon their wauing pendants.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Rage not, but lets resolue what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Let some ride post to Creete for menelaus.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: That be my charge.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Who'le after him to Sea?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That wil my brother Castor and my selfe,
And perish there, or bring my sister backe.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Princes be't so, and fairely may you speed:
Whilst I to Agamemnon, great Achilles,
Vlysses, Nestor, Aiax, Idomean,
And all the Kings and Dukes of populous Greece,
Relate the wrongs done by this Rauisher.
Part, and be expeditious.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
I smelt this Sea-rat ere he came a shoare, by this hee's gnawing
Menelaus Cheese, and made a huge hole in't. Ship-dyet pleaseth
'boue all his Pallace banquets, much good doo't them:
They are at it without grace by this both bare:
Cuckold? no subiect with that name bee sorry,
Since Soueraignes may be such in all their glory.

div.head: Actus secundus Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Faire Cresida, by the honour of my birth,
As I am Hectors brother, Priams sonne,
And Troilus best belou'd of Hecuba,
As I loue Armes and souldiers, I protest,
Thy beauty liues inshrin'd heere in my brest.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: As I am Calchas daughter, Cresida,
High Priest to Pallas, shee that patrons Troy:
Now sent vnto the Delphian Oracle,
To know what shal betide Prince Paris voyage.
I hold the loue of Troilus dearer farre.
Then to be Queene of Asia.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Daughter to Calchas and the pride of Troy,
Plight me your hand and heart.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Faire Heauen I doe.
Will Troilus in exchange grant me his too?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Yes, and fast seal'd, you gods, your anger wreak
On him or her, that first this vnion breake.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: So protests Cresida, wretched may they dye,
That 'twixt our soules these holy bands vntye.

div.stage: Enter Margaretan one of Priams youngest sonnes.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: My brother Troilus, we haue newes from Greece,
Prince Paris is return'd.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: And with a prise?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Asia affoords none such.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: What is shee worth our Aunt Hesione?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Or what might be her name?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Hellen of Sparta.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Hellens name
Hath scarce been heard in Troy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: But now her fame
Will bee eterniz'd, for a face more faire
Sunne neuer shone on, nor the earth ere bare.
Why stay you here? by this Paris and shee
Are landed in the Port of Tenedos,
There Priam, Hecuba, Hector, all Troy
Meets the mid-way to attend the Spartan Queene.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: In that faire Traine, my Cresid shal be seene
Of rarer beauty then the Spartan Queene.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter at one doore, Priam, Hecuba, Hector, Troilus, &c. At the other Paris, Hellen, Aeneas, Antenor, &c.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What Earth, what all mortality
Can in the height of our inuentions finde
To adde to Hellens welcome, Troy shall yeeld her.
Should Pallas, Patronesse of Troy descend,
Priam and Priams wife, and Priams sonnes
Could not afford Her god-head more applause,
Then amply wee bestow on Helena?

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: We count you in the number of our daughters,
Nor can wee doe Queene Hellen greater honour.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I was not forward to hane Paris sent,
But being return'd th'art welcome: I desired not
To haue bright Hellen brought, but being landed,
Hector proclaimes himselfe her Champion
'Gainst all the world, and he shall guard thee safe
Despight all opposition.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hectors word
As Oracle, hee'le seale it with his sword.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And now my turne comes to bid Hellen welcome.
You are no stranger here, this is your Troy,
Priam your father, and this Queene your mother:
These be your valiant brothers, all your friends.
Why should a teare fall from these heauenly eyes
Being thus round ingirt with your allyes.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am I know not where, nor amongst whom,
I know no creature that I see saue yon:
I haue left my King, my brothers, subiects, friends
For strangers, who should they forsake me now,
I haue no husband, father, brother neare:

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Haue you not all these, is not Paris heere?
Harke how the people hauing Hellen seene
Applaud th'arriuall of the Spartan Queene:
And millions that your comming haue attended,
Amazed sweare some Goddesse is descended.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: No way you can your eyes or body turne,
But where you walke the Priests shall Incense burne.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: The sacrificed beasts the ground shall beate,
And bright religious fire the Altars heate.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Nor feare the bruite of warre or threatning steele,
Vnited Greece wee value not.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Alone, by Hector is this Towne well man'd,
Hee like an Army against Greece shall stand.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And who would feare for such a royall wife
To set the vniuersall World at strife:
Bright Hellens name shall liue, and nere haue end,
When all the world about you shall contend.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Be as be may, since we are gone thus farre,
Proceede we will in spight of threatned warre,
Hazard, and dread? both these we nothing hold,
So long as Paris we may thus infold.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My father, mother, brothers, sisters all,
Illium and Troy in pompe maiesticall,
Shall solemnize our nuptials. Let that day
In which we espouse the beauteous Hellena,
Be held a holy-day, a day of ioy
For euer, in the Kalenders of Troy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: It shall be so, we haue already sent
Our high priest Calchas to the Oracle
At Delphos to returne vs the successe,
And a true notice of our future warres,
Whilst we expect his comming, be't our care,
The Spartans second nuptials to prepare.

div.stage: Enter after an alarum, King Agamemnon, Menelaus Achilles, Aiax, Patroclus, Thersites, Calchas, &c.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Thou glory of the Greekes, the great commander
Of the stout Mirmedons: welcome from Delphos,
What speakes the Oracle? the sacke of Troy?
Or the Greekes ruine? say shal wee be victors,
Or Priam tryumph in our ouerthrow.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: The god of Delphos sends you ioyful newes,
Troy shal be sackt, and we be Conquerors:
Vpon your helmes weare triple spangled plumes:
Let all the lowdest instruments of warre,
With sterne alarums rowse the monster death,
And march we boldly to the wals of Troy,
Troy shall be sackt and we be conquerors.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Thanks for thy newes Achilles, by that honor
My father wonne vpon the wals of Troy.
My warlike father Aiax Telamon;
I would not for the world, Priam should send
Incestious Hellen backe on tearmes of peace.
May smooth Vlisses and bold Diomed,
Whom you haue sent on your late Embassie,
Be welcom'd as Antenor was to Greece,
Scorn'd and reuil'd, since th' Oracle hath sayd,
Troy shal be sackt, and we be Conquerors.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: King Agamemnon heere's a Troian priest
Was sent by Priam to the Oracle:
The reuerent man I welcome, and intreate
The General with these Princes, do the like.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Welcome to Agamemnon reuerent Calchas.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: To Menelaus welcome.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: To Aiax welcome: father canst thou fight
As wel as pray, if we should want for men?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: By prayers I vse to fight, and by my counsel
Giue ayde to Armes.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Such as are past armes, father Calchas still,
Say counsels good, but giue me strength at will,
When you with all your Counsel, in the field
Meete Hector with his strength, tel me who'le yeeld?

sp.speaker: Aga,
sp.l: The strong built walls of stately Tenedos
We haue leuel'd with the earth. It now remaines
We march along vnto the wals of Troy,
And thunder vengeance in King Priams eares,
Had we once answere of our Embassie.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I euer held such Embassies as base,
The restitution of our rauisht Queene
On termes of parley bars our sterne reuenge,
And ends our War ere fully it beginne.
King Agamemnon no, Aiax sayth no,
Whose sword as thirsty as the parched earth,
Shal neuer ride in peace vpon his thigh,
Whilst in the towne of Troy there breathes a soule
That gaue consent vnto the Spartans rape:
March, march, and let the thunder of our drummes
Strike terrour to the Citty Pergamus.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: The sonne of Telamon speakes honourably,
Wee haue brought a thousand ships to Tenedos,
And euery ship full fraught with men at Armes:
And all these armed men with fiery spirits
Sworne to reuenge King Menelaus wrongs,
And burne skie-kissing lllium to the ground.
Therefore strike vp warres Instruments on hye,
And march vnto the Towne couragiously.

div.stage: In their march they are met by Vlysses and King Diomed, at which they make a stand.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Princes, what answere touching Hellena?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What answere but dishonourable tearme?
Contempt and scorne pearcht on their leaders browes,
By Ioue I thought they would haue slaine vs both.
If euer Hellen bee redeem'd from thence
But by the sacke of Troy, say Diomed
Is no true souldier.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Euen in the King
There did appeare such high maiesticke scorne
Of threatned ruine, that I thinke himselfe
Will put on Armes and meete vs in the field:
Wee linger time great Agamemnon, march,
That we may buckle with the pride of Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Priam so insolent, his sonnes so braue
To intertaine so great Embassadours
With such vngentle vsage.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: They haue a Knight cal'd Hector, on whose valour
They build their proud defiance, if I meete him,
Now by the azurd Armes of that bright goddesse
From whom I am descended, with my sword
I'le loppe that limbe off, and inforce their pride
Fall at Achilles feete, Hector and I
Must nor both shine at once in warres bright Skie.

sp.speaker: Aiax
sp.l: When they both meete, the greater dimme the lesse,
Great Generall, march, Aiax indures not words
So well as blowes, in a field glazd with swords.

div.stage: Enter to them in Armes, Priam, Hector, Troilus, Paris, Aeneas, Antenor, Deiphobus, &c.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Calchas a Traitour?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And amongst the Greekes?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Base runagate wretch, when we their Tents surprise,
As Hector liues the traiterous Prophet dies.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Let not remembrance of so base a wretch
Make vs forget our safety, th' Argiue Kings
Are landed, and this day rac't Tenedos:
And bid vs battaile on Scamander Plaines.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Whom we will giue a braue and proud affront;
Shall we not brother Hector?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troilus yes,
And beate a fire out of their Burgonets
Shall like an earthy Commet blaze towards Heauen
There grow a fixt starre in the Firmament
To emblaze our lasting glory: Harke their Drums,
Let our Drummes giue them parleance.

div.stage: A parlie. Both Armies haue an enter-view.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Is there amongst your troopes a fellon Prince
Cal'd by the name of Paris?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is there amongst your troopes a Knight so bold
Dares meete that Paris single in the field,
And call him fellon?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Or insulting Greeke,
Is there one Telamon, dares set his foote
To Paris (here hee stands) and hand to hand
Maintaine the wrongs done to Hesione,
As Paris shall the rape of Helena.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Know here is one cal'd Aiax Telamon,
Behold him well, sonne to that Telamon:
Thou faine would'st see, and hee dares set his foot
To Paris or thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thou durst not.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Dare not?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Or if thou durst, by this my warlike hand
I'le make thine head fall where thy foot should stand:
And yet I loue thee cuze, know thou hast parlie'd
With Troian Hector.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Were't thou ten Hectors, yet with all thy might
Thou canst not make my head fall to my feete,
By Ioue thou canst not cuze.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I much haue heard
Of such a Knight cal'd by the name of Hector,
If thou bee'st hee whose sword hath conquerd Kingdomes,
Pannonia, Illyria, and Samothrace,
And to thy fathers Empire added them:
Achilles as a friend wils thee to sheath
Thy warlike sword, retire from Troyes defence
And spare thy precious life, I would not haue
A Knight so fam'd meete an vntimely graue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I meet thee in that honourable loue,
And for thine owne sake wish thee safe aboord.
For if thou stayest thou sonne of Peleus,
I'd haue thee know thy fame is not thine owne,
But all ingrost for mee; not all thy guard
Of warlike Mirmidons can wall it safe
From mighty Hector.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Shame you not great Lords
To talke so long ouer your menacing swords?

sp.speaker: All Greeks.
sp.l: Alarme then for Greece and Helena.

sp.speaker: All Troians.
sp.l: As much for vs, for Troy and Hecuba.

div.stage: A great alarme and excursions, after which, enter Hector and Paris.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Oh brother Paris, thou hast this day lodg'd
Thy loue in Hectors soule, it did me good
To see two Greekish Knights fall in their blood
Vnder thy manly arme

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My blowes were touches
Vnto these ponderous stroakes great Hector gaue.
Oh that this generall quarrell might be ended
In equall opposition, you and I
Against the two most valiant.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I will try
The vertue of a challenge, in the face
Of all the Greekes I will oppose my selfe
To single combate, hee that takes my gage
Shall feele the force of mighty Hectors rage.

div.stage: A turne. Both the Armies make ready to ioyne battaile, but Hector steps betwixt them holding vp his Lance.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Heare mee you warlike Greekes, you see these fields
Are all dyde purple with the reeking gore
Of men on both sides slaine, you see my sword
Glaz'd in the sanguine moysture of your friends.
I call the sonne of Saturne for a witnesse
To Hectors words I haue not met one Grecian
Was able to withstand mee, my strong spirit
Would faine be equal'd: Is there in your Troupes
A Knight, whose brest includes so much of valour
To meete with Hector in a single warre?
By Ioue I thinke there is not: If there be?
To Him I make this proffer; if the gods
Shall grant to him the honour of the day,
And I be slaine; his bee mine honoured Ar mes,
To hang for an eternall Monument
Of his great valour, but my mangled body
Send backe to Troy, to a red funerall pile.
But if hee fall? the armour which hee weares
I'le lodge as Trophies on Apolloes shrine,
And yeeld his body to haue funerall rights.
And a faire Monument so neere the Sea,
That Merchants flying in their sayle-wing'd ships
Neere to the shoare in after times may say,
There lies the man Hector of Troy did slay,
And there's my Gantlet to make good my challenge.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Will none take vp his gage? shall this proud challenge
Bee Intertain'd by none? I know you all
Shame to deny, yet feare to vndertake it:
The cause is mine, and mine shall be the honour
To combat Hector.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Menelaus pawse,
Is not Achilles here, sterne Aiax here,
And Kingly Diomed? how will they scorne,
That stand vpon the honour of their strength,
should you preuent them of this glorious combat.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: By Ioue I thinke they dare as well take vp
A poysonous Serpent as great Hectors gage.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Yes Troian, see'st thou not Aeacides
Dart emmulous lookes on Kingly Diomed,
Least hee should stoope to take his Gantlet vp.
And see how Diomed eyes warlike Aiax,
Aiax, Vlysses: euery one inflam'd
To answere Hector.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is there any here
Dares stoope whilst great Achilles is in place?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I dare.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And so dare I.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: You are all too weake
To incounter with the mighty Hectors arme,
This combat soly doth belong to mee.

sp.speaker: Aiax
sp.l: Then wherefore do'st not thou take vp the Gantlet?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: To see if thou or any bolder Greeke
Dare be so insolent to touch the same,
And barre me of the honour of the combat.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: By all the gods I dare.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: And all the diuells
I'le loppe his hands off that dares touch the gage.

sp.speaker: Ulyss.
sp.l: Pray leaue this emulous fury: Agamemnon,
To end this difference, and prouide a Champion
To answers Hectors honourable challenge
Of nine the most reputed valiant:
Let seuerall Lots be cast into an Helme,
Amongst them all one prise, he to whom Fortune
Shall giue the honour: let him straight be arm'd
To incounter mighty Hector on this plaine.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: It shal be so you valiant sonnes of Priam:
Conduct your warlike Champion to his Tent,
To breath a while, and put his armour on:
No sooner shal the prise be drawne by any,
And our bold Champion arm'd, but a braue Herald
Shall giue you warning by the trumpets sound,
Till when we will retire vnto our Tents.
As you vnto the Towne.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Faint hearted Greekes,
Draw lots to answere such a noble challenge,
Had great Achilles cast his Gauntlet downe
Amongst King Priams sonnes, the weakest of fifty
Would in the heate of flames, or mouth of Hel,
Answere the challenge of so braue a King.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Greekes to your Tents, to put armour on;
Make hast, I long to know my Champion.

div.stage: Flourish. Enter aboue vpon the wals, Priam, Hecuba, Hellena, Polixena, Aftianax, Margareton. with attendants.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Here from the wals of Troy, my reuerent Queene,
And beautious Hellen, we will stay to see
The warlicke combate 'twixt our valiant sonne,
And the Greekes champion. Young Astianax,
Pray that thy father may haue Victory.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.l: Why should you doubt his fortune? whose strong arme
Vnhorst a thousand Knights all in one day;
And thinke you any one amongst the Greekes
Is able to incounter with his strength?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But howsoeuer child, vnto the pleasure
Of the high gods, we must referre the combate.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My royall father, Hector in his armes
Sends for your blessing, with the Queene my mother,
And craues your prayers to the all powerful gods,
To grant him victory.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Blest may he be with honor, all my orisons
Shall inuocate the gods for his successe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I almost had forgot faire Hellena;
Dart me one kisse from these high battlements
To cheere him with: thanks queen these lips are charms
Which who so fights for, is secure from harmes.

div.stage: Heralds on both sides: the two Champions Hector and Aiax appeare betwixt the two Armies.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: None presse too neere the Champions.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Heralds on both sides, keep the souldiers back.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Now Greekes let me behold my Champion.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Tis I, thy cousen Aiax Telamon.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: And Cuz, by Ioue thou hast a braue aspect,
It cheeres my blood to looke on such a foe:
I would there ran none of our Troian blood
Inall thy veines, or that it were diuided
From that which thou receiuest from Telamon:
Were I assured our blood possest one side,
And that the other; by Olimpicke Ioue,
I'd thrill my Iauelin at the Grecian moysture,
And spare the Troian blood: Aiax I loue it
Too deare to shed it, I could rather wish
Achilles the halfe god of your huge army,
Had beene my opposite.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Hee keepes his Tent
In mournful passion that he mist the combate:
But Hector, I shal giue thee cause to say,
There's in the Greekish hoast a Knight a Prince,
As Lyon hearted, and as Gyant strong
As Thetis sonne: behold my warlicke Target
Of pondrous brasse, quilted with seauen Oxe hides,
Impenetrable, and so ful of weight,
That scarse a Grecian (sane my selfe) can lift it:
Yet can I vse it like a Summers fan,
Made of the stately traine of Iuno's bird:
My sword will bite the hardest Adamant.
I'le with my Iauelin cleaue a rocke of Marble:
Therefore though great Achilles be not here,
Thinke not braue cousen Hector but to finde,
Achilles equal both in strength and minde.

div.stage: Alarum, in this combate both hauing lost their swords and Shields. Hector takes vp a great peece of a Rocke, and casts at Aiax; who teares a young Tree vp by the rootes, and assailes Hector, at which they are parted by both armes.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Hold, you haue both shed blood too deare to loose,
In single opposition.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is your Champion,
My cousen Aiax willing to leaue combate;
Will hee first giue the word.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Sir Paris no,
'Twas Hector challenge, and 'tis Hectors office,
If we surcease on equal termes of valour,
To giue the word.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Then here's thy cousins hand,
By Ioue thou hast a lusty pondrous arme:
Thus till we meete againe, lets part both friends;
For proofe whereof Aiax we'le interchange
Somewhat betwixt vs, for alliance sake:
Here take this sword and target, trust the blad,
It neuer deceiu'd his maister.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Take of me
This purple studded belt, I won it cousen
From the most valiant prince of Samothrace:
And weare it for my sake.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Priam vnto the Greekish General
This profer makes. Because these blood-stayn'd fields
Are ouer-spread with slaughter, to take truce
Till all the dead on both sides be interr'd:
Which if you grant, he here inuites the Generall,
His nephew Aiax, and the great Achilles,
With twenty of your chiefe selected Princes,
To banquet with him in his royal Pallace:
Those reuels ended, then to armes againe.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: A truce for burying of the slaughtred bodies
We yeeld vnto: but for our safe returne
From Troy and you, what pledges haue you found?

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: You shal not need more then the faith of Hector
For Priams pledge, King Agamemnon take
My faith and honour, which if Priam breake,
Ile breake the heart of Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: We'le take your honor'd word, this night we'le part,
To morrow morning when fit hower shal call,
We'le meete King Priam neere his Citties wall.

div.head: Actus Tertius Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Braue time, rare change, from fighting now to feasting:
So many heauy blades to flye in peeces
For such a peece of light flesh? what's the reason?
A Lasse of my complexion, and this feature
Might haue bin rapt, and stolne agayne by Paris,
And none of all this stirre for't: but I perceiue
Now all the World's turn'd wenchers, and in time
All wenches will turne witches: but these Trumpets
Proclaime their enter-view.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter all the Greekes on one side, all the Troians on the other: Euery Troian Prince intertaines a Greeke, and so march two and two, discoursing, as being conducted by them into the Citty.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: See here's the picture of a polliticke state,
They all imbrace and hugge, yet deadly hate:
They say their are braue Lasses in this Troy.
What if Thersites sprucely smug'd himselfe,
And striu'd to hide his hutch-backe: No not I.
Tis held a rule, whom Nature markes in show
And most deformes, they are best arm'd below.
I'le not conceale my vertues: yet should I venter
To damme my selfe for painting, fanne my face
With a dyde Ostritch plume, plaster my wrinkles
With some old Ladies Trowell, I might passe
Perhaps for some maide-marrian: and some wench
Wanting good eye-sight, might perhaps mistake me
For a spruce Courtier: Courtier? tush, I from
My first discretion haue abhor'd that name,
Still suiting my conditions with my shape,
And doe, and will, and can, when all else fayle:
Though neither sooth nor speak wel: brauely rayle,
And that's Thersites humour.

div.stage: Lowd Musicke. A long table, and a banquet in state, they are seated, a Troian and Greeke, Hecuba, Polixena, Cresida, and other Ladies waite, Calchas is present whispering with his Daughter Cresida.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: After so much hostility in steele,
All welcome to this peacefull intertaine.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Priam wee know thee to be honourable,
Although our foe Treason is to be fear'd
In Pesants not in Princes.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Ey so, now sit a Troian and a Greeke.
Cousin Aiax neere mee, you are next in bloud,
And neere mee you shall sit: the strayne of honour
That makes you so renown'd, sprong from Hesione.
Tis part of Hectors bloud, your grosser spirits
Lesse noble are your father Telamons.
Welcome to Troy, and Hector, welcome all:

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: In Troy thy kinsman, but in field thy foe:
Thy welcome Cousin here I pay with thanks,
The truice expir'd, with buffets blowes and knocks.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: For that wee loue the Cuze.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Me thinks this Troian Hector
Out shines Achilles and his polisht honours
Ecclipseth our bright glory, till hee set
Wee cannot rise.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: King Menelaus, we were once your guest,
You now are ours, as welcome vnto Troy,
As we to Sparta.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: But that these our tongues
Should be as well truce bound as our sharpe weapons,
We could be bitter Paris: but haue done.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Menelaus is discreet, such haynous wrongs
Should be discours'd by Armes and not by tongues.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why doth Achilles eye wander that way?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is that a Troian Lady?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Shee is.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Of vs.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Her name?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Polyxena.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Polixena? she hath melted vs within,
And hath dissolu'd a spirit of Adamant.
Shee hath done more then Hector and all Troy,
Shee hath subdu'de Achilles.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: In one word this Troy shall be sackt and spoil'd,
For so the gods haue told mee, Greece shall conquer,
And they be ruin'd, leaue then imminent perill,
And flye to safety.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: From Troilus?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: From destruction, take Diomed and liue,
Or Troilus and thy death.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Then Troilus and my ruine.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Is Cresid mad?
sp.p: Wilt thou forsake thy father, who for thee and for thy safety hath forsooke his Countrey?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Must then this Citty perish?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Troy must fall.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Alas for Troy and Troilus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Loue King Diomed
A Prince and valiant, which made Emphasis
To his Imperiall stile, line Diomeds Queene,
Be briefe, say quickly wilt thou? is it done?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Diomed and you I'le follow, Troilus shun.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Bee't Aiax, or Achilles, that Greeke lyes
Who speakes it, I'le maintaine it on his person.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Ha Aiax!

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Achilles!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: We speake it, and dares Troilus say we lie?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: And weare it Diomed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Dar'ft thou make't good?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: On Diomed, or the boldest Greeke
That euer manac'd Troy excepting none.

sp.speaker: All Greeks.
sp.l: None?

sp.speaker: All Troians.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Excepting none.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Kings of Greece.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Princes of Troy.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Achilles bafled?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: And great Aiax bran'd?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: If great Achilles, Aiax, or the Diuel braue Troilus, hee shall braue and buffer thee.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Sonnes.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Fellow Kings.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: As wee are Priam and your father.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: As wee are Agamemnon Generall
Turne not this banquet to a Centaus feast,
If their be strife debate it in faire termes,
Show your selues gouern'd Princes.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Wee are appeas'd

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Wee satisfied, if Hector be so.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: How grew this strife?

sp.speaker: Hect
sp.l: I know not, onely this I know.
Troilus will maintaine nothing against his honour,
And so farre, be it through the heart of Greece,
Hector will backe him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So will Paris too.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Mildly discourse your wrongs, faire Princes doe.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: King Diomed maintaines his valour thus,
He saith it was his Launce dismounted Troilus,
And not the stumbling on the breathlesse course
Of one new slaine that feld mee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It was my fortune to make good that field,
And hee fell iust before mee, Diomed then
Was not within sixe speares length of the place.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: How Troian rauisher?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Call mee not Cuckold maker,
I care not what you terme me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I cannot brooke this wrong.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Say'st thou mee so madde Greeke?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Paris.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Gouerne you Kingdomes Lords, and cannot sway
Your owne affection?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Paris, forbeare.
Mildly discourse, and gently wee shall heare.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I say King Diomed vnhorst not Troilus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How came I by his horse then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: As the vnbackt courser hauing lost his rider,
Gallopt about the field you met with him,
And catch'd him by the raine.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Here was a goodly act
To boast on, and send word to Cresida.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Was no Prince neare when I encountred Troilus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I was, and saw the speare of Diomed
Tumble downe Troylus but peruse his armour▪
The dint's still in the vainbrace.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Bee't so or not so, at this time forbeare
To vrge extreames. Kings let this health go round,
Pledge me King Priam in a cupful crown'd.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Now after banquet, reuels: Musicke strike
A pirhicke straine, we are not all for warre,
Souldiers their stormy spirits can appease,
And sometimes play the Courtiers when they please.

div.stage: A lofty dance of sixteene Princes, halfe Troians halfe Grecians.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I haue obserued Achilles, and his eye
Dwels on the face of faire Polixena.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Why is not Hellen here at this high feast?
I haue sweat many a drop of blood for her,
Yet neuer saw her face.

sp.speaker: Achi
sp.l: I could loue Hector, what's our cause of quarrel?
For Hellens rape? that rape hath cost already
Thousands of soules, why might not this contention
'Twixt Paris and the Spartan King be ended,
And we leaue Troy with honour.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Achilles how?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Fetch Hellen hether, set her in the midst
Of this braue ring of Princes, Paris here,
And Menelaus heere: she betwixt both:
They court her ore againe, whom she elects
Before these Kings, let him inioy her still,
For who would keepe a woman gainst her wil?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The names of wife and husband, th'interchange
Of our two bloods in young Hermione,
To whom we are ioynt parents, Hellens honor
All pleade on my part, I am pleasde to stand
To great Achilles motion.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So are we.
All that I haue for comfort is but this,
That in the day I show the properer man,
ith' night I please her better then hee can.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Are all the Greecian Kings agreed to this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are, we are.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Place the two riuals then, each bide his fate,
And vsher in bright Hellen in all state.

div.stage: The Kings promiscuously take their places, Paris and Menelaus are seated opposite, Hellen is brought in betwixt them by Hecuba and the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh that I were (but Hellen) any thing;
Or might haue any obiect in my eye
Saue Menelaus: when on him I gaze,
My errour chides mee, I my shame emblaze.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Oh Hellen, in thy cheeke thy guilt appeares,
More I would speake, but words are drown'd in teares,

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: A gallant Queene, for such a royall friend
What mortall man would not with Ioue contend?

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Hellen the time was I might call thee wife,
But that stile's changed; I, thou thy selfe art chang'd
From what thou wast: and (most inconstant Dame)
Hast nothing left thee, saue thy face and name.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: And I both these haue: hast thou not confest
Faire Hellen, thy exchange was for the best.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What can our Sparta value?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Troy.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: You erre.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: who breathes that Sparta would 'fore Troy prefer.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Thou hast left thy father Tendarus.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: To gayne
King Priam, Lord of all this princely trayne.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Thy mother Lada thou hast left who mournes,
And with her piteous teares laments thy losse:
Cannot this mooue thee?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh I haue left my mother.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No Hellen, but exchang'd her for another:
Poore Leda, for rich Hecuba, a bare Queene
For the great Asian Empresse.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: From Castor and from Pollux thou hast rang'd
Thy naturall brothers.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No, but chang'd,
For Hector, Troilus, and the royall store
Of eight and forty valiant brothers more.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: If nothing else can moue thee Helena,
Thinke of our daughter young Hermione.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My deare Hermione.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Canst thou call her deare,
And leaue that issue which thy wombe did beare?
Shee's ours betwixt vs, canst thou?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Can shee? knowing,
A sweeter babe within her sweete wombe growing
Begot last night by Paris.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Looke this way Hellen, see my armes spread wide,
I am thine husband, thou my Spartan bride.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That way?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My Hellen, this way turne thy sight,
These are the armes in which thou layest last night.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Oh how this Troian tempts mee!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This way wife,
Thou shalt saue many a Greeks and Troians life.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I know it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This way turne thine head,
This is the path that leades vnto our bed.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: And 'tis a sweete smooth path.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Heere.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Heere.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Take this way Hellen, this is plaine & euen.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That is the way to hell, but this to Heauen:
Bright Comet shine this way.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Cleare starre shoot this,
Here honour dwels.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here many a thousand kisse.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That way I should, because I know 'tis meeter.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Welcome.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But I'le this way for Paris kisses sweeter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And may I dye an Eunuch if ere morne
I quit thee not.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I cannot brooke this scorne,
Grecians to Armes.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Then Greece from Troy deuide,
This difference armes, not language most decide.

sp.speaker: All Greekes.
sp.l: Come to our Tents.

sp.speaker: All Troians.
sp.l: And wee to man the towne.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: These Tents shall swimme in bloud.

sp.speaker: Greekes.
sp.l: Blood Troy shall drowne.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Yet shall no stroke fall from Achilles arme,
Faire Polixena, so powerfull is thy charme.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: King Diomed!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: My riuall in the loue of Cresida.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: False Cresida, iniurious Diomed.
Now shall I prooue in hostile enter-change
Of warlike blowes that thou art all vnworthy
The loue of Cresid.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why cam'st thou not on Horse-backe,
That Diomed once againe dismounting thee
Might greete his Lady with another course
Wonne from the hand of Troilus.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Diomed,
By the true loue I beare that trothlesse Dame
I'le winne thee, and send thy Horse and Armour
Vnto the Tent of Cresid guard thy head,
This day by mee thou shalt be captiue led.

div.stage: Alarme. They fight and are parted by the army, Diomed looseth his Helmet.

sp.speaker: Troi
sp.l: Another Horse for Diomed to flye,
Hee had neuer greater neede then now to runne.
Though hee be fled yet Troilus this is thine.
My Steed hee got by sleight, I this by force.
I'le send her this to whom hee sent my horse.

div.stage: Enter Aeneas and Achilles reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is this the answere of the note I sent
To royall Priam and Queene Hecuba,
Touching their daughter bright Polixena?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Behold Queene Hecubaes hand, King Priams seale,
With the consent of faire Polixena,
Condition'd thus, Achilles shall forbeare
To dammage Troy.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Returne this answer backe,
Tell Priam that Achilles Arme's benumb'd,
And cannot lift a weapon against Troy.
Say to Queene Hecuba wee are her sonne,
And not Achilles, nor one Mirmidon
Shall giue her least affront, as for the Lady
Bid her presume, we henceforth are her Knight,
And but for her, Achilles scornes to fight.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Then thus saith Priam, but restraine thy powers,
And as hee is a King, his daughter's yours.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Achilles, where's Achilles, what vnarm'd,
when all the Champaigne where our battailes ioyns,
Is made a standing poole of Greekish blood,
Where horses plung'd vp to the saddle skirts,
And men aboue the waste wade for their lines,
And canst thou keepe thy Tent?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My Lute Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let Greekes, kill Greekes, let's bend vnnaturall armes
Against our owne brests, ere the conquering Troians
Haue all the honour of this glorious day.
Can our great Champion touch a womanish Lute,
Aud heare the grones of twenty thousand soules
Gasping their last breath?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: I can.

div.l: Rescue, some rescue, the red field is strowd
With Hectors honours and young Troilus spoyles.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Yet all this moues not me.

sp.speaker: Ulyss.
sp.p: How long hath great Achilles bin surnam'd Coward in Troy, that Hector, Troilus, Paris, haue all that name so currant in their mouthes?
sp.l: I euer held him valiant, yet will Achilles fight?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Vlysses, no,
Beneath this globe Achilles hath no foe.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Then here vnarm'd be slaine, think'st thou they'l spare
Thee more then vs?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Or if thou wilt not arme thee,
Let thy Patroclus lead thy Mirmidons,
And weare thy Armour.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Thy Armour is sufficient
Without thy presence being fear'd in Troy.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: To saue our oath and keepe our Tents from sacke,
Patroclus don our Armes, lead forth our guard,
And wearing them by no Prince be out-dar'd.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Achilles honours me, what heart can feare,
And great Achilles sword proofe Armour weare?

div.stage: Exeunt all the Princes, enter Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Where's this great sword and buckler man of Greece?
Wee shall haue him one of sneakes noise,
And come peaking into the Tents of the Greeks,
With will you haue any musicke Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Base groome, I'l teare thy flesh like falling Snow.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: If I had Hectors face thou durst not doo't.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Durst not?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Durst not, hee's in the field, thou in thy Tent,
Hector playing vpon the Greekish burgonets,
Achilles fingring his effeminate Lute.
sp.p: And now because thou durst not meete him in the field, thou hast counterfeited an humour of loue. Achilles?
Thou the Champion of Greece, a meere bug-beare, a scar-crow, a Hobby-horse.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Vlisses taught thee this, deformed slaue.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Coward thou durst not do this to Hector.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: On thee Ile practise, til I meete with him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Aiax is valiant, and in the throng of the Troians,
Achilles is turn'd Fidler in the Tents of
The Grecians.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Diomed wounded, bringing in Patroclus dying.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Looke here Achilles.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Patroclus?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: This wound great Hector gaue:
Reuenge my death, before I meets my graue.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Yet will Achilles fight? see Aiax wounded,
Two hundred of thy warlike Mirmedons
Thou hast lost this day.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Let's beate him to the field.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Had I lost a Patroclus, a deere friend
As thou hast doue, I would haue dond these armes
In which he dyed, sprung through the Troian hoast,
And mauger opposition, let the blow
Or by the same hand dy'd: come ioyne with me,
And we without this picture, statue of Greece,
This shaddow of Achilles, will once more
Inuade the Troian hoast.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Aiax?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Achilles?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Wee owe thee for this scorne.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I scorne that debt:
Thou hast not fought with Hector.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My honor and my oath both combate in mee:
But loue swayes most.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Our ships are fir'd, fiue hundred gallant vessels
Burnt in the Sea, halfe of our Fleete destroy'd,
Without some present rescue.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Doth no man aske where is this double fire,
That two wayes flyes towards heauen?
Vpon the right our royall Nauy burnes,
Vpon the left, Achilles Tents on fire.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Our Tent?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: By Ioue thy Tent, and all thy Mirmedons,
Haue not the power to quench it: yet great Hector
Hath shed more blood this day, then would haue seru'd
To quench, both Fleete and Tent.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My sword and armour:
Polixena, thy loue we will lay by,
Till by this hand, that Troian Hector dye.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I knew he must be fired out.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Hector, Paris, Troilus, Aeneas, with burning staues and fire-bals.

sp.speaker: Al the Troians.
sp.l: Strike, stab, wound, kill, tosse firebrands, and make way.
Hector of Troy, and a victorious day.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Well fought braue brothers.

sp.speaker: Pia
sp.l: What's hee?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Tis Aiax, downe with him.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: No man presume to dart a feather at him
Whilst we haue odds: cousen if thou seekest combate?
See we stand single, not one Troian here,
Shall lay a violent hand vpon thy life,
Saue wee our selfe.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Cousen th'art honorable,
I now must both intreate and coniure thee,
For my old Vncle Priams sake, his sister
Hesione my mother, and thine Aunt:
This day leaue thine aduantage, spare our Fleete,
And let vs quench our Tents, onely this day
Stay thy Victorious hand, tis Aiax pleades,
Who but of Ioue hath neuer begg'd before,
And saue of Ioue, will not intreate againe.

sp.speaker: Al Troians.
sp.l: Burne, still more fire.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Ile quench it with his blood
That addes one sparke vnto this kindled flame:
My cousin shall not for Hesiones sake
Be ought denide of Hector, she's our Aunt:
Thou, then this day hast sau'd the Grecian Fleete:
Let's sound retreat, whose charge made al Greece quak,
We spare whole thousands for one Aiax sake.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Worthiest a liue thou hast, Greece was this day
At her last cast, had they pursude aduantage:
But I deuine, hereafter from this hower,
We neuer more shal shrinke beneath their power.

div.head: Actus Quartus Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Hector, Troilus, Paris, Aeneas, Hectors armour bearer, with others.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: My armour, and my trusty Galatee,
The proudest steed that euer rider backt,
Or with his hoofes beate thunder from the earth,
The Sunne begins to mount the Easterne hill,
And wee not yet in field: Lords yesterday
Wee slipt a braue aduantage, else these ships
That floate now in the Samothracian road,
And with their wauing pendants menace Troy,
Had with their flames reflecting from the Sea,
Gilt those high towers, which now they proudly braue.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: On then; Achilles is vnconquered yet,
Great Agamemnon and the Spartan King,
Aiax the bigge-bond Duke of Salamine,
With him that with his Lance made Kenus bleed,
The bold, (but euer rash) King Diomed.
To lead these captiue through Scamander Plaines,
That were a taske worth Hector.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: Why not vs?
Yet most becomming him, come then Aeneas,
Let each Picke one of these braue Champions out
And single him a captiue.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: 'Twere an enterprise
That would deserue a lasting Chronicle:
Lead on renowned Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Vnnimble slaue,
Dispatch, make hast, I would be first in field,
And now I must be cal'd on.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Oh stay deare Lord, my royall husband stay▪
Cast by thy shield, fellow vncase his armes,
Knock off the riuets, lay that baldricke by,
But this one day rest with Andromache.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: What meanest thou woman?

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: To saue my honoured Lord
From a sad fate, for if this ominous day,
This day disastrous, thou appear'st in field
I neuer more shall see thee.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Fond Andromache.
Giue me some reason for't.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: A fearefull dreame,
This night me thought I saw thee 'mongst the Greekes
Round girt with squadrons of thine enemies,
All which their Iauelins thrild against thy brest,
And stucke them in thy bosome.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: So many Squadrons,
And all their darts quiuerd in Hectors brest,
Some glanc't vpon mine armour, did they not?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Did none of all these darts rebound from Hector
And hit thee sister, for (my Lasse) I know,
Thou hast been oft hit by thine Hector so.

sp.speaker: Andro.
sp.l: Oh doe not iest my husband to his death,
I wak't and slept, and slept and wak't againe:
But both my slumbers and my sounde sleepes
Met in this one maine truth, if thou this day
